snippet.textDisplay: Have you tried the "fu" version of these masks? I love the pattern from Joost De Cock. One thing I've read online is that doctors and nurses wearing these all day (thank goodness for these heroes right now!) prefer masks that either tie around the head or use elastic around the head, rather than elastic around the ears. Thanks for your pattern, I'm going to try yours - perhaps with some experimental modifications!
snippet.textOriginal: Have you tried the "fu" version of these masks? I love the pattern from Joost De Cock. One thing I've read online is that doctors and nurses wearing these all day (thank goodness for these heroes right now!) prefer masks that either tie around the head or use elastic around the head, rather than elastic around the ears. Thanks for your pattern, I'm going to try yours - perhaps with some experimental modifications!

snippet.textDisplay:
Wow, I'm so glad I looked this up. My mamaw, who passed 09/09 last year, was a huge arts and crafts enthusiast. She sewed little summer dresses every year for Hati.

Now I am 36, been 20 years since almost 30 years since l used a sewing machine, but I'm a fast learner.

And if I can start churning these out in five minutes, then as my mamaw would say, "You done a good job there."

I feel so worried for our first responders, for families not able to visit their sick relative, to individuals dying suddenly, alone on top of that and then if you're lucky a graveside service of a few.

So to anyone out there, working the front lines, donating your time and money, I salute you! Know I pray for you and all of us everyday!

To those suffering any negativity from this situation, a sick loved one, I'm also praying for you. It's scary for all but no matter if you're Christian, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim, Atheist.... believe in something!

And to each and every American, hang in there. We're a long ways from finished. A "flattening of the curve" is only a start.

If anyone needs to talk, my email is uk389117 at Gmail.

And I thank you OP for such a thorough but quick tutorial. I seen six minutes or so runtime and thought, hmm, this may work!
snippet.textOriginal:
Wow, I'm so glad I looked this up.  My mamaw, who passed 09/09 last year, was a huge arts and crafts enthusiast.  She sewed little summer dresses every year for Hati.

Now I am 36, been 20 years since almost 30 years since l used a sewing machine, but I'm a fast learner.

And if I can start churning these out in five minutes, then as my mamaw would say, "You done a good job there."

I feel so worried for our first responders, for families not able to visit their sick relative, to individuals dying suddenly, alone on top of that and then if you're lucky a graveside service of a few.

So to anyone out there, working the front lines, donating your time and money, I salute you!  Know I pray for you and all of us everyday!

To those suffering any negativity from this situation, a sick loved one, I'm also praying for you.  It's scary for all but no matter if you're Christian, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim, Atheist.... believe in something!

And to each and every American, hang in there.  We're a long ways from finished.  A "flattening of the curve" is only a start.  

If anyone needs to talk, my email is uk389117 at Gmail.  

And I thank you OP for such a thorough but quick tutorial.  I seen six minutes or so runtime and thought, hmm, this may work!

snippet.textDisplay: These masks are great and easy to make. But they primarily work to help keep people from touching their face with their hands (that may have picked up the virus ), they will not filter out the virus. The virus is mostly contracted from hand to face/mouth/nose/eyes, so you'll know if you try to touch your face - you'll touch your mask instead. Wear these when out in stores especially, also wear glasses! Then wash your hands. Thanks for the tutorial!
snippet.textOriginal: These masks are great and easy to make. But they primarily work to help keep people from touching their face with their hands (that may have picked up the virus ), they will not filter out the virus. The virus is mostly contracted from hand to face/mouth/nose/eyes, so you'll know if you try to touch your face - you'll touch your mask instead. Wear these when out in stores especially, also wear glasses! Then wash your hands. Thanks for the tutorial!

snippet.textDisplay: My hospital (in Chicago) needs these masks! All providers are wearing masks (universal masking) in order to protect others from being infected when a asymptomatic provider is at work. We have been told to wash them at home in between shifts. We are still wearing appropriate medical masks or N95 masks when caring for patients with respiratory symptoms. But wearing cloth masks for other patients will mean we can save the medical masks for those situations where they are absolutely necessary. Thank you so much to those of you who can make these masks! I encourage you to reach out to your local hospitals to inquire if they are looking for donations of these masks.
snippet.textOriginal: My hospital (in Chicago) needs these masks! All providers are wearing masks (universal masking) in order to protect others from being infected when a asymptomatic provider is at work. We have been told to wash them at home in between shifts. We are still wearing appropriate medical masks or N95 masks when caring for patients with respiratory symptoms. But wearing cloth masks for other patients will mean we can save the medical masks for those situations where they are absolutely necessary. Thank you so much to those of you who can make these masks! I encourage you to reach out to your local hospitals to inquire if they are looking for donations of these masks.

snippet.textDisplay: We made professionally hand-sewn re-washable face masks in a manufacturing facility in Los Angeles.  The masks come with an expensive MERV 16 level filter sewn into the mask. MERV 16 can catch particles even smaller than coronavirus and are breathable.  We planned on selling on Amazon / eBay at reasonable prices but Amazon shut down selling of masks. Can anyone direct us who should we contact?
snippet.textOriginal: We made professionally hand-sewn re-washable face masks in a manufacturing facility in Los Angeles.  The masks come with an expensive MERV 16 level filter sewn into the mask. MERV 16 can catch particles even smaller than coronavirus and are breathable.  We planned on selling on Amazon / eBay at reasonable prices but Amazon shut down selling of masks. Can anyone direct us who should we contact?

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you!  I hope people will pay attention to your warning that these DO NOT protect you from the virus. snippet.textDisplay:
I believe there should be some basic requirements for the fabric, the outer layer should be waterproof like tarp, the middle layer should filter virus and air particulate like 3M air filter material which will be better to be a layer able to be replaced after use. The liner fabric should be able to absorb droplets and vapor people breathe out like cotton.

However, this is a very useful video, and many thanks!
snippet.textOriginal:
I believe there should be some basic requirements for the fabric, the outer layer should be waterproof like tarp, the middle layer should filter virus and air particulate like 3M air filter material which will be better to be a layer able to be replaced after use. The liner fabric should be able to absorb droplets and vapor people breathe out like cotton.

However, this is a very useful video, and many thanks!

snippet.textDisplay: Ok, so my significant other picked up from fabric from Joanne's Fabric Store and this has been a complete disaster. There was no elastic available, so some different lengths of ribbon were given in it's place - 16 inch and 22 inch if I recall correctly which was a great alternative. The printed/written instructions I received were extremely difficult to follow (and used elastic in the description), so I started looking on Google for videos to help me understand the instructions a little better, and it led me here. After making the template, I carefully cut out the doubled-over fabric and began sewing the first part with the 2 1/2 inch gap. Then, I got to the part where the elastic is used. When I try to do what this person does with the elastic and use the ribbon instead, the person's head would have to be like a horse in order for the loops to go around their ears. The only other video that remotely touched on facemasks the woman starts talking about 4-layer cotton and so on, so clearly I am out of my league here... and who irons edges during a war-like production run? I thought the goal was to make simple masks that would prevent projectiles from reaching the person that was wearing it... I am so dejected right now... I wanted to help and have spent the last 2+ hours watching this and other videos. I grew up around seamstresses, tailors and dry cleaners, and still can't get this. I hope others have better success in this task!
snippet.textOriginal: Ok, so my significant other picked up from fabric from Joanne's Fabric Store and this has been a complete disaster. There was no elastic available, so some different lengths of ribbon were given in it's place - 16 inch and 22 inch if I recall correctly which was a great alternative. The printed/written instructions I received were extremely difficult to follow (and used elastic in the description), so I started looking on Google for videos to help me understand the instructions a little better, and it led me here. After making the template, I carefully cut out the doubled-over fabric and began sewing the first part with the 2 1/2 inch gap. Then, I got to the part where the elastic is used. When I try to do what this person does with the elastic and use the ribbon instead, the person's head would have to be like a horse in order for the loops to go around their ears. The only other video that remotely touched on facemasks the woman starts talking about 4-layer cotton and so on, so clearly I am out of my league here... and who irons edges during a war-like production run? I thought the goal was to make simple masks that would prevent projectiles from reaching the person that was wearing it... I am so dejected right now... I wanted to help and have spent the last 2+ hours watching this and other videos. I grew up around seamstresses, tailors and dry cleaners, and still can't get this. I hope others have better success in this task!

snippet.textDisplay: Good news! The SEIU union has located and is selling 39 MILLION N95 masks and say they will be delivered to NY and California in the next week. They have also have discovered additional suppliers who would be able to produce another 20 million masks per week and millions of face shields. Also, Honeywell and 3M have been ramping up production for at least a month. Kudos to all volunteers making these masks
snippet.textOriginal: Good news! The SEIU union has located and is selling 39 MILLION N95 masks and say they will be delivered to NY and California in the next week. They have also have discovered additional suppliers who would be able to produce another 20 million masks per week and millions of face shields. snippet.textDisplay: I just finished making one of your face masks.  I have made 3 others with a similar pattern.  I liked the idea of the flannel but had a very difficult time sewing over the pleated part of the mask.  Is there some setting on my machine that I can change to make it easier?  I have a Janome.   Also  does it make a difference if it has 2 or 3 pleats?  I have been asked to make masks for the case workers who still go into the homes of foster children.  Also when the home health nurse came to visit my ill husband, she did not have a mask on. I asked why she wasn't wearing one and she said they didn't have any. I also plan on making those nurses some masks. Need help with the those pesky pleats though. Hope you can help me. Thanks so much,  Kathy, At Home in  the Missouri Ozarks.
snippet.textOriginal: I just finished making one of your face masks.  I have made 3 others with a similar pattern. snippet.textDisplay: Pls do not use flannel - its is absorbent and will take the water out of your breath and make the mask wet, it is also TOO HOT, if you make one and test it and wear it for 10 mins, you will know that its too hot to wear! Erica I hope you won't delete my message as this it to help everyone protect themselves, The Fabric Patch lady is a nurse and she has made 3 very informative tutorials with a lot of info for the masks, this is to save lives its important to know what you can and if they are made with flannel they will get thrown out, you want your efforts to count.

snippet.textDisplay: Coronavirus is safe to use n94.  However, it is difficult to obtain it now and the price is high.  Viruses are spread from person to person by droplets.  That's why cotton masks help.  However, cotton masks have large particles.  Put a lot of coffee filters inside the mask inside.  It will be much better.  This article uses Google Translator.

snippet.textDisplay: I made about 5 of these, but i felt there was too much "gap" at the top and bottom; also, i ran out of elastic, so now i just have ribbon. So i decided to make some changes!!!  I have a lot of interfacing, which seems perfect for this. I did away with making the pleats, too much trouble. Now, i just use one layer of material, and one layer of interfacing and i make channels on the sides to put the ribbon through. I cut the ribbon about 12 1/2 inches long and once it is in the channel, i put s stitch across the middle of it to hold it there and then i can gather the sides and tie a knot in the ribbon (making a loop for behind the ears). This seems to fit more snugly. So i am sticking with that design. I still use bread ties to make the nose shape on the top edge, that is also inside the top edge.  Thanks to everyone who is making these!!!  Good luck to you.
snippet.textOriginal: I made about 5 of these, but i felt there was too much "gap" at the top and bottom; also, i ran out of elastic, so now i just have ribbon. So i decided to make some changes!!!  I have a lot of interfacing, which seems perfect for this. I did away with making the pleats, too much trouble. Now, i just use one layer of material, and one layer of interfacing and i make channels on the sides to put the ribbon through. I cut the ribbon about 12 1/2 inches long and once it is in the channel, i put s stitch across the middle of it to hold it there and then i can gather the sides and tie a knot in the ribbon (making a loop for behind the ears). This seems to fit more snugly. So i am sticking with that design. I still use bread ties to make the nose shape on the top edge, that is also inside the top edge.  Thanks to everyone who is making these!!!  Good luck to you.

snippet.textDisplay: EXCELLENT Tutorial!  Thank you for this!  Some of my former co-workers in the hospital lab are using these fabric masks over the top of their n95 masks in order to extend the usage of the n95.  Essential they use the cotton mask to cover the n95 mask while working with a patient. When finished with the patient they then remove the cotton one, putting it in the laundry, which allows them to use the previously covered n95 mask again.  Your tutorial was succinct and very effective.
snippet.textOriginal: EXCELLENT Tutorial!  Thank you for this!  Some of my former co-workers in the hospital lab are using these fabric masks over the top of their n95 masks in order to extend the usage of the n95.  Essential they use the cotton mask to cover the n95 mask while working with a patient. When finished with the patient they then remove the cotton one, putting it in the laundry, which allows them to use the previously covered n95 mask again.  Your tutorial was succinct and very effective.

snippet.textDisplay:
Make sure the inside and outside are different tightly woven fabrics. The masks are used over and over again and the staff needs to be sure they keep the same side to their face.
If you run out of elastic make cloth ties of about 18 to 20 inches long
Thank you for making them
snippet.textOriginal:

Thank you for making them

snippet.textDisplay: This video was super helpful and easy to follow along! One thing though is that I found the elastic to be too long. I made a prototype based on this video and showed it to my friend who is a doctor who had asked that I help make masks for her hospital, and she said that the elastic should be cut down by at least 1/3 of the size (I did find the mask to fit quite loosely). Other than that, this is a great video thanks for sharing!
snippet.textOriginal: This video was super helpful and easy to follow along! One thing though is that I found the elastic to be too long. I made a prototype based on this video and showed it to my friend who is a doctor who had asked that I help make masks for her hospital, and she said that the elastic should be cut down by at least 1/3 of the size (I did find the mask to fit quite loosely). Other than that, this is a great video thanks for sharing!

snippet.textDisplay: I've been watching a lot of these mask tutorials over the past few days, trying to decide which style of mask construction seems the best to me so that I can make a choice and get going. I just want to say that your mask style is probably the best in that it comes together quickly and includes a middle layer. But more importantly, YOU are the best teacher by far. I love that you don't waste time chattering or trying to be funny, but just get right down to business and move through the instructions steadily and swiftly. Instructions were also very easy to understand. Thank you so much for this tutorial. I feel confident that I know what to do now.
